> <span key="d0727240c4474fcdae3f8bdbc26679fd">*The goal of AI is to create computer models that exhibit “intelligent behaviors” like humans, according to*<span offset-key="d0727240c4474fcdae3f8bdbc26679fd:1"> </span></span><a href="https://www.csail.mit.edu/person/boris-katz" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="4fa60da5e70d4cf483a360886a257332" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-3426_259-3427-237__"><span data-key="60c0ca0c6d454bd5aa634bc97c6b8ff2"><em>Boris Katz</em></span></span></a><span key="6b42a6bddaee48cb9829b8b7aad96b8c">*, a principal research scientist and head of the InfoLab Group at CSAIL. This means machines that can recognize a visual scene, understand a text written in natural language, or perform an action in the physical world.*</span>

> <span key="cc15ac1d86b1447aa5e5b6efa6fc1f6c">*Machine learning is one way to use AI. ## 

<span key="ca53a3dad8af42bab6ec2e75077da9e2"><span offset-key="ca53a3dad8af42bab6ec2e75077da9e2:0">Natural language processing</span></span>

<span key="071ea7f94cc04a65b30d2acb53402d24"><span offset-key="071ea7f94cc04a65b30d2acb53402d24:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><span slate-void="true" key="67a7f3e06fb54d19bd906a40a7cdb8a1"></span>

<span key="52745fcb3e794129823d0f7232b619b8"><span offset-key="52745fcb3e794129823d0f7232b619b8:0">Natural language processing is a field of machine learning in which machines learn to understand natural language as spoken and written by humans, instead of the data and numbers normally used to program computers. This allows machines to recognize language, understand it, and respond to it, as well as create new text and translate between languages. Natural language processing enables familiar technology like chatbots and digital assistants like Siri or Alexa.</span></span><span slate-void="true" key="5086b56477a74a9e8ae52b52d06b2aeb"></span>

<span key="78a3579abda9455ea3c1fe2e4f14deb7"><span offset-key="78a3579abda9455ea3c1fe2e4f14deb7:0">### Neural networks</span></span><span slate-void="true" key="16f1304fc2944a4fbe54d54cde4309e6"></span>

<span key="9ea59e4c0f4f4988a4369e2d304640a1"><span offset-key="9ea59e4c0f4f4988a4369e2d304640a1:0">Neural networks are a commonly used, specific class of machine learning algorithms. Artificial neural networks are modeled on the human brain, in which thousands or millions of processing nodes are interconnected and organized into layers.</span></span>

<span key="31692d113c344ed4a22a9e5a40462156"><span offset-key="31692d113c344ed4a22a9e5a40462156:0">In an artificial neural network, cells, or nodes, are connected, with each cell processing inputs and producing an output that is sent to other neurons. Labeled data moves through the nodes, or cells, with each cell performing a different function. In a neural network trained to identify whether a picture contains a cat or not, the different nodes would assess the information and arrive at an output that indicates whether a picture features a cat.</span></span>
